snippet: Inscriptions on a wall of what appeared to be a studio for royal scribes in Guatemala may date to the early ninth century, several hundred years older than the examples previously known.
abstract: Archaeologists publish report in journal Science showing that house discovered in the ruins of a large Maya city in northeastern Guatemala appears to be a studio for royal scribes and calendar priests from the early ninth century; murals and inscriptions found on walls of the site suggest that calendar writing may have been well advanced several centuries earlier than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: Inscriptions on a wall of what appeared to be a studio for royal scribes in Guatemala may date to the early ninth century, several hundred years older than the examples previously known.

headline.seo: Archaeologists Unearth Ancient Maya Calendar Writing
headline.main: Painted Maya Walls Reveal Calendar Writing
headline.print_headline: Painted Maya Walls Reveal Calendar Writing
